articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description: Sacha Greif openly wondered whether CSS has gotten to be, you know, too big. With all the goodies that’ve shipped in browsers the past couple of years — container queries! relative color syntax! cascade layers! logical properties…
articles.title: What CSS Do You Absolutely Have to Know in 2022?

articles.author: Ganesh Dahal
articles.description: The way we write CSS for WordPress themes is in the midst of sweeping changes. I recently shared a technique for adding fluid type support in WordPress by way of theme.json, a new file that WordPress has been pushing …
articles.title: Managing CSS Styles in a WordPress Block Theme

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
“A change to overflow on replaced elements in CSS”:
From Chrome 108, the following replaced elements respect the overflow property: img, video and canvas. In earlier versions of Chrome, this property was ignored on these elements.
This 
…
articles.title: A Couple Changes Coming in Chrome 108

articles.author: Aisha Bukar
articles.description: Web Sockets, Web Workers, Service Workers… these are terms you may have read or overheard. Maybe not all of them, but likely at least one of them. And even if you have a good handle on front-end development, there’s a …
articles.title: The Difference Between Web Sockets, Web Workers, and Service Workers

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description: Every once in a while, the blogging zeitgiest seems to coalesce around a certain topic and it’s like the saved articles in my bookmarks folder are having a conversation. The conversation sitting in there now is all about CSS Gradients …
articles.title: Some Links About CSS Gradients

articles.description: This is a continuation of my last article about “Rendering External API Data in WordPress Blocks on the Front End”. In that last one, we learned how to take an external API and integrate it with a block that …
articles.title: Rendering External API Data in WordPress Blocks on the Back End

articles.author: Preethi Selvam
articles.description: The Media Queries Level 4 specification has introduced a new syntax for targeting a range of viewport widths using common mathematical comparison operators, like , and =, that make more sense syntactically while writing less code for responsive web design.
articles.title: The New CSS Media Query Range Syntax

articles.author: Temani Afif
articles.description: We’ve spent the last two articles in this three-part series playing with gradients to make really neat image decorations using nothing but the element. In this third and final piece, we are going to explore more techniques using the …
articles.title: Fancy Image Decorations: Outlines and Complex Animations

articles.author: Bradley Kouchi
articles.description:
Simon Goellner (@simeydotme)’s collection of Holographic Trading Cards have captured our attention.
Under the hood there is a suite of filter(), background-blend-mode(), mix-blend-mode(), and clip-path() combinations that have been painstakingly tweaked to reach the desired effect. I …
articles.title: Holographic Trading Card Effect

articles.author: Brecht De Ruyte
articles.description: The CSS :has() pseudo class is rolling out in many browsers with Chrome and Safari already fully supporting it. It’s often referred to it as “the parent selector” — as in, we can select style a parent element from a …
articles.title: Creating Animated, Clickable Cards With the :has() Relational Pseudo Class

articles.author: Sacha Greif
articles.description: As front-end developers, we’ve wished for a lot of things over the years — ways to center things in CSS, encapsulate styles, set an element’s aspect ratio, get finer-grained control over our colors, select an element based on its children’s …
articles.title: Is There Too Much CSS Now?

articles.author: Temani Afif
articles.description: Welcome to Part 2 of this three-part series! We are still decorating images without any extra elements and pseudo-elements. I hope you already took the time to digest Part 1 because we will continue working with a lot of gradients …
articles.title: Fancy Image Decorations: Masks and Advanced Hover Effects

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description: I love it when there’s a sense of synergy in the blogosphere. First, I caught Nick Heer’s coverage of Meta ending support for Instant Articles, its proprietary format for stripped-down performant news articles. He also compares it to the similar …
articles.title: Instant Articles, Proprietary Syndication, and a Web Built on User Fidelity Preferences

articles.author: Cassie Evans
articles.description:
Before I career jumped into development, I did a bunch of motion graphics work in After Effects. But even with that background, I still found animating on the web pretty baffling.
Video graphics are designed within a specific ratio and …
articles.title: Responsive Animations for Every Screen Size and Device

articles.author: Preethi
articles.description: When you put something — say a regular sheet of paper — in a manilla folder, a part of that thing might peek out of the folder a little bit. The same sort of thing with a wallet and credit …
articles.title: How to Make a Folder “Slit” Effect With CSS

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Everything design systems on accessibility, enterprise design systems, Figma kits, data visualization, motion design, multi-lingual design, naming, ROI calculator and UX writing.
articles.title: Design Systems: Useful Examples and Resources

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Atila Fassina)
articles.description: Let’s talk about Next.js, one of the most well-known React frameworks used for production. From new components to font optimization, Atila shares a quick overview and invites you to join his [Advanced Next.js Masterclass](https://smashingconf.com/online-workshops/workshops/advanced-nextjs-atila-fassina) taking place later this month.
articles.title: What’s New In Next.js 13?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Siobhan McKeown)
articles.description: Transparency is part of the fabric of many remote businesses. It doesn’t, however, come naturally to everyone, especially if you’ve only recently become remote. In this article, Siobhan takes you through some of the practical ways that you can build transparency within your organization.
articles.title: Practical Steps To Build Transparency In Your Remote Business

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Iris Lješnjanin)
articles.description: What’s the state of HTML Email, Vue.js and Next.js? Would you like to level up with modern CSS? What are new, smart interface design patterns we could use? Let’s figure it all out together with our [brand new online workshops](https://smashingconf.com/online-workshops/) alongside our free community meetups.
articles.title: New Smashing Front-End & UX Workshops

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: When designing navigation on mobile, we don’t have to rely on slide-in-menus or nested accordions. We can also use the curtain design pattern, and show multiple levels of navigation at once.
articles.title: Designing The Perfect Mobile Navigation UX

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (William Lyon)
articles.description: If building a GraphQL API backed by a native graph database sounds interesting or at all helpful for the problems you’re trying to solve as a developer, perhaps you’d like to give the open-source [Neo4j GraphQL Library](https://srv.buysellads.com/ads/long/x/TCZPLYDDTTTTTTFR6JINCTTTTTTGVUIVKKTTTTTTCT2NTYYTTTTTTI4BVH7U4JBCKQ466IDGV2IUWESGCV7WALL5QYYE) a try. Let’s take a closer look at the reasons why!
articles.title: Putting The Graph In GraphQL With The Neo4j GraphQL Library

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: November is just around the corner, and with it, a new collection of desktop wallpapers to celebrate the beginning of the month. Designed by creatives from all across the globe, they come in versions with and without a calendar. Let’s make November colorful!
articles.title: On The Edge Of November (2022 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Yosra Emad)
articles.description: In this article, Yosra Emad explains how to create a rollercoaster path that a ball follows using cubic beziers and CSS transitions. You’ll also learn how the cubic-bezier function in CSS works in detail and how to stack multiple simple animations to create one complex one.
articles.title: How To Create Advanced Animations With CSS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Yaphi Berhanu)
articles.description: If you've ever wanted to build a web app that you can control with hand gestures as if by magic, this article is for you. With a couple of APIs and some JavaScript, you can build apps that behave like sorcery.
articles.title: Motion Controls In The Browser

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Alma Hoffmann)
articles.description: In this article, Alma Hoffmann discusses six basic variables to establish a typographic hierarchy, explains how to look at each differently, and in turn, designs pieces by intentionally modifying each variable to create a typographic hierarchy effectively.
articles.title: Typographic Hierarchies

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Lea Verou)
articles.description: The annual survey for anyone who writes CSS, [State of CSS](https://stateofcss.com/en-us/?source=smashing_magazine_css_survey), is nearing the end of its response period for 2022. The survey is available in many different languages and all questions are optional.
articles.title: State Of CSS Survey: Influence The Future Of CSS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Sacha Greif)
articles.description: In this article, Sacha Greif tries to anticipate future CSS trends and takes a look at some far-fetched and futuristic CSS features that might one day make their way to the browser.
articles.title: Futuristic CSS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Patrick Brosset)
articles.description: In this article, Patrick Brosset gives an update on the most impactful new features that are now available in DevTools, across Firefox, Chrome, Safari, and Edge.
articles.title: What’s New In DevTools: Halloween Edition 🎃

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Meet Understanding Privacy, our brand new Smashing Book to make sense of privacy, and learn how to create inclusive, safe and privacy-aware digital experiences. eBook now available, print shipping in late November.
articles.title: Understanding Privacy: A New Smashing Book Is Here

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Nick Schäferhoff)
articles.description: In this article, Nick Schäferhoff will take a deep dive into WordPress Full-Site Editing, examine the tools it provides for theme development, and provide a tutorial on how to use it to make changes to your site.
articles.title: WordPress Full-Site Editing: A Deep Dive Into The New Feature

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andrii Zhdan)
articles.description: In this article about conducting productive meetings, Andrii Zhdan will give you a step-by-step guide on preparing a solid meeting structure that will let you follow the original plan and reach the meeting goals, and he will also share a few tips based on his design experience.
articles.title: Effective Communication For Everyday Meetings

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Michelle Barker)
articles.description: Climate change and sustainability are increasing concerns for digital organizations, as well as individuals working in tech. In this article, we’ll explore some of the ways we can raise awareness and effect change within an organization to create a more positive environmental impact.
articles.title: Sustainable Web Development Strategies Within An Organization

articles.author: Md. Fahim Bin Amin
articles.description: If you are running Linux OS, you've likely already heard about mirror repositories. According to Quora, > In Linux, a mirror is a copy of programs available for download. If you are close (in networking terms, maybe or maybe not geographically) to one of the mirror sites listed, you might
articles.title: How to Download Applications Fast Using Mirrors On Manjaro Linux

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: CTFs and Wargames can help people their improve command line and hacking skills.  The Bandit wargame from OverTheWire is aimed at absolute beginners. It is a game you connect to through SSH that will help you will improve your command line skills, your linux skills, and you hacker skills.
articles.title: Improve Your Cybersecurity Command Line Skills – Bandit OverTheWire Game Walkthrough

articles.author: Beau Carnes

We just published a course on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel that will teach you about microservice architecture and distributed systems using a hands-on approach.  Georgio from Kantan Coding teaches this
articles.title: Microservices and Software System Design Course

articles.author: Kolade Chris
articles.description: If you’re a developer that works with Node JS and JavaScript libraries and frameworks like React, Vue, and Angular, then you might have encountered the "Error: cannot find module" error. In this article, I’m going to show you how to fix the error. Why the "Error: cannot find module" Occurs
articles.title: Error: cannot find module [Node npm Error Solved]

articles.author: Matthes Bär
articles.description: In this step-by-step tutorial, you'll learn how to easily start with Unit Tests in React. You'll learn how to write tests for Redux states as well as fundamental Redux slice tests using the React Testing Library and Jest. 🔐 Here's What We'll Cover  * You'll see how easy it
articles.title: How to Write Unit Tests in React – Basic Redux Toolkit Testing Included

articles.author: Nishant Kumar
articles.description: Hey everyone! OpenAI just released its DALL-E API where users can generate custom images by just typing in a query.  So in this tutorial, you'll learn how to integrate the OpenAI DALL-E 2 API with a React app. But First, How Does Dall-E Work? So as you already know,
articles.title: How to Generate Images using React and the Dall-E 2 API – React and OpenAI API Tutorial

articles.author: Arunachalam B
articles.description: In 2017, I bought a new laptop and switched to Linux. I started off with Ubuntu (but jumped to Elementary [https://elementary.io/] later), as most people suggested it was beginner friendly.  People also suggested that I should get used to using the keyboard and terminal over a mouse to enjoy
articles.title: How to Learn the Linux Terminal as a Beginner – Tips and Examples

articles.author: Deji Adesoga
articles.description: When building a web application, toggling an element is one of the key features you are likely to come across and may need to implement in your project. There are various ways you can toggle an element. In this article, we will take a look at how we can implement
articles.title: How to Toggle an Element in React using React Hooks

articles.author: Jessica Wilkins
articles.description: Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) represents the design for a web page. But when you are learning this information for the first time, it can be hard to keep track of all of the different CSS properties. In this article, I have created a study guide for the freeCodeCamp curriculum's entire
articles.title: Learn CSS – Responsive Web Design Study Guide

articles.author: Daniel Adetunji
articles.description: High availability, fault tolerance and disaster recovery are important things to consider when designing a system.  These terms are sometimes used interchangeably by architects and developers. They are not, however, the same thing – and understanding the differences can save you many headaches, as well as time and money.
articles.title: High Availability vs Fault Tolerance vs Disaster Recovery – Explained with an Analogy
